reference_textbooks: Management Information Systems: Managing the Digital Firm by Laudon & Laudon
course_description: Study of information systems in organizations, focusing on how technology enables business strategy and operations.

topics: Introduction to MIS
Information Systems in Business
ER Diagram and Database
Database Planning (Data Planning, Requirements Specification, Conceptual Design, Logical Design, Physical Design)
Chapter Objectives (Logical database design, Converting ER diagrams to relational tables, Need for data normalization)
Entity-Relationship (E-R) Model (Diagramming entities and relationships)
E-R Model Entity and its attributes (Salesperson example, primary key)
Primary Key
Binary Relationships
Cardinality (One-to-One, One-to-Many, Many-to-Many Binary Relationships)
Modality
Intersection Data (Used with many-to-many relationships)
Converting a Simple Entity (to a table)
Converting Entities in Binary Relationships:
Converting One-to-One Relationship (Options #1, #2, #3)
Converting One-to-Many Relationship (Foreign key on the 'many' side)
Converting Many-to-Many Relationship (Three relational tables, intersection data/associative entity)
The Data Normalization Process (Eliminating redundancy)
Normalization Forms (First, Second, and Third Normal Form examples)

lecture_slides.lecture_name: Digital Business, Models, and Decision Making
topics: Digital Business & Model
Decision Making (Chogwatpol case, Amazon marketing, Tata green innovation)
Traditional vs. Digital Business (Tech as core competency, Data-driven decision)

Core Information System, Strategy, and Competitive Edge of Digital Platforms
Digital Business Types (Transaction, Market, E-tailer, Broker, Creator, Content/Community/Service Provider)
Revenue Models (Advertising, Free/Freemium, Subscription, Affiliate, Sales, Transaction)
Final Thoughts (Behavioural Targeting, Wisdom of Crowds)
Introduction to Power BI

lecture_slides.lecture_name: Value Chain, Business Model Canvas, and Business Intelligence
topics: Value Chain Analysis and the Role of IS
Porter's Value Chain (Inbound/Outbound Logistics, Operations, Sales/Marketing, Service, Firm Infrastructure, R&D, Procurement)
Information Systems supporting the Value Chain (CRM, SCM, CAD, CAM, DSS, ESS)
The Business Model Canvas (Key Partners, Activities, Resources, Value Propositions, Customer Segments, Relationships, Channels, Revenue Streams, Cost Structure)
Business Intelligence (BI) for Decision Support
BI Infrastructure (Data Warehouses, Data Marts, Analytic Platforms)
Business Analytics Toolset (Models, Data Mining, OLAP, Big Data analytics)
Expert Systems
BCG (Growth Share) Matrix
Power BI Dashboard
Disruptive Technologies (Steam engine, Electricity, Telephone/TV, Internet)
Rogers' Innovation Adoption Model (Innovators, Early Adopters, Early/Late Majority, Laggards)
Cloud Computing: Motivation, Issues, and Definition
Cloud Computing Market Trends and Growth
Metacomputing (Definition, Harnessing idle cycles, Performance)
Metacomputing Characteristics/Issues (Heterogenous, Task scheduling, Fault tolerance, Load balancing, Communication overheads)
Examples of Metacomputing Systems (LYDIA, SPAWN, Condor, Popcorn, Milan, Java Market)
Client/Server Paradigms
Core Definition and Scope of a Product (Anything offered to a market to satisfy a want or need, including goods, services, and experiences)
Product Classification (Dividing products into Industrial and Consumer types based on purchase purpose)
Detailed Consumer Product Categories (Classification based on customer buying behavior: Convenience, Shopping, Specialty, and Unsought Products)
The Three Levels of Product (Modeling a product's value proposition across Core Customer Value, Actual Product Attributes, and Augmented Product Services)
Key Product Attributes (Defining Product Quality and its components like Performance Quality, Conformance Quality, Branding, and Packaging)
The Stages of the Product Life Cycle (PLC) (Analyzing sales, profit, costs, customers, and competitors across Introduction, Growth, Maturity, and Decline stages)
PLC Marketing Strategies (Outlining distinct strategies for Product, Price, Distribution, Advertising, and Sales Promotion for each PLC stage)
PLC Curve Variations (Examining non-standard life cycle patterns: Growth-Decline, Cycle-Recycle, Innovative/Scalloped, and the differences between Style, Fashion, and Fad)
The Ansoff Growth Matrix (Using the 2x2 matrix to identify corporate growth strategies: Market Penetration, Product Development, Market Development, and Diversification)

The Boston Consulting Group (BCG) Matrix (Using the 2x2 matrix of Market Growth Rate vs. Relative Market Share to classify products/SBUs as Stars, Cash Cows, Question Marks, and Dogs, and determining appropriate strategies)
Product, Service, and Experience (Moving beyond product/service to customer experience)
Services vs. Products
Four Characteristics of Services: **Intangibility**, **Variability**, **Inseparability**, and **Perishability**
The Service Profit Chain and Three Types of Service Marketing (External, Internal, and Interactive Marketing)
Defining **Product Policy** and key decisions for a firm
Concepts of **Product Mix/Portfolio**, **Product Line**, and **Consistency** of the mix
Product Line Decisions: **Product Line Length**, **Depth** (and Stock-Keeping Unit - SKU)
Product Line Strategies: **Line Extension** (Upward/Downward Stretch, Filling) and **Line Pruning**
Recap/Application of the **Boston Consulting Group (BCG) Matrix** (Stars, Cash Cows, Question Marks, Dogs)
The Eight Major Stages of the **New-Product Development (NPD) Process**
Detailed look at: **Idea Generation** (Internal, External, Open Innovation/Crowdsourcing)
**Idea Screening** (Real, Win, Worth doing - R-W-W Framework)
**Concept Development and Testing** (Product Idea, Concept, Image)
**Marketing Strategy Development** and **Business Analysis**
**Product Development** (Alpha and Beta Testing)
**Test Marketing** (Challenges and Types: Standard, Controlled, Simulated) and **Commercialization**
Definition of **Price** (Narrow and Broad Sense) and its importance as a marketing tool and source of revenue
Identifying the **Price Floor** (Product Costs) and **Price Ceiling** (Customer Perceptions of Value)
Company Pricing Objectives (Survival, Maximum Profit/Market Share, Quality Leadership)
Major Pricing Strategies: **Customer Value-Based**, **Cost-Based**, and **Competition-Based Pricing**
External and Internal Factors Affecting Pricing Decisions (Nature of the Market/Demand, Competitors, Economic Conditions)
The **Supply Chain** and **Value Delivery Network** (Upstream vs. Downstream)
Definition and function of a **Marketing Channel** (Distribution Channel)
Marketing Channel Functions (Information, Promotion, Contact, Matching, Negotiation, Physical Distribution)
Channel Organization: **Vertical Marketing Systems** (VMS) and **Horizontal Marketing Systems**
**Channel Conflict** (Vertical and Horizontal) and **Disintermediation**
Key Decisions in **Designing a Marketing Channel** (Consumer needs, Objectives, Alternatives, Evaluation)
Psychological and Reference Pricing (e.g., Pricing Cues, Price-Quality Perception)
**New-Product Pricing Strategies** (Market-Skimming vs. Market-Penetration Pricing)
**Product Mix Pricing Strategies** (Product Line, Optional, Captive, By-Product, Bundle Pricing)
**Price Adjustment Strategies** (Discounts and Allowances, Promotional Pricing, Segmented Pricing)
**Price Discrimination** (1st, 2nd, and 3rd Degree)
**Dynamic Pricing** (Yield Management, Demand-based Pricing) and **Geographical Pricing**
**Price Discovery** methods (Negotiations, Group Buying, **Auctions**)

reference_textbooks: Statistics for Business: Decision Making and Analysis by Robert E Stine and Dean Foster, Pearson (ISBN: 978-81-317-3347-9)
course_description: Regression models are among the most powerful statistical models used in business analysis. This course introduces students to the concepts of regression by modeling dependent behavior and relationships among variables, followed by analysis of covariance and logistic regression as a classifier. The objective is to help students identify relationships, use predictive models and analyze correlations.

topics: Fitting Equations to Data
Transformations
Least squares fitting criteria
Point prediction from regression equation

Non-linear transformation
Polynomial transformation

Outliers

Correlation matrix
Interpreting Multiple Regression
Inference in Multiple Regression
Building Regression Models

Comparison of regression models

Strategies for dealing with Collinearity
Variance Inflation Factor (VIF)
Categorical Explanatory Variables
Two sample comparisons
Analysis of Covariance (ANCOVA)
Interactions and inference
Use of categorical variables in regression models
Logistic Regression

course_description: This course explores the concept of Customer Experience (CX) and Branding, covering the new consumer behavior, the CX framework, customer journey mapping, experiential marketing, and future challenges in the digital landscape. It also includes an introduction to UX design tools.

topics: Major Trends and Evolution of the New Consumer
Three key changes in Consumer Behavior (Digital transformation, Consumer Empowerment, The key role of Emotion)
Digital Transformation: Technological, Demographic, and Socio-Economic Drivers
Consumer Empowerment: Competency, (Re)Creation, Consciousness, and Resistance
The key role of Emotion: Emotional Branding
What is Customer Experience?
Introduction to UX design
Origins of the 'Experience' Concept (Lived experience, Philosophical, and Sociological approach)
From 'Experience' to 'Customer Experience' (Roots in Marketing, The Emergence of CX/Failure of CRM)
Customer Experience definition (Lemon & Verhoef, 2016)
A framework for conceptualizing consumer experience
The Customer Journey (Overview, Pre-purchase/Purchase/Post-purchase stages, Types of Touch Points, McKinsey purchasing funnel)
The construction of Personas (Definition, Why use them, Creation process)
UX Research
Le Wagon briefing
